newsitem.title: CANADA: Tone improves on Quebec/Newfoundland hydro talks.
newsitem.headline: Tone improves on Quebec/Newfoundland hydro talks.

text.p: There has been a positive change in tone for talks between Quebec and Newfoundland on renegotiating the controversial Churchill Falls hydroelectric contract, a senior Quebec cabinet minister said on Thursday.
"There has been a change in tone between Quebec and Newfoundland," Natural Resources Minister Guy Chevrette told reporters.
Chevrette was commenting on discussions between Quebec and Newfoundland on the hydroelectric power contract between Hydro-Quebec and Churchill Falls (Labrador) Corp.

At issue is the long-term contract under which Labrador's Churchill Falls sells roughly 30 billion kilowatt hours of power each year to Hydro-Quebec at low rates, which the Quebec-owned utility then sells at a significant markup to domestic and U.S. customers.

Under the contract, which runs to 2041, the rates Hydro-Quebec pays for power from the 5,420 megawatt Churchill Falls facility decline over time and Newfoundland has said it would soon begin losing money on the deal.
Newfoundland has long demanded that Quebec renegotiate the contract for an more equitable split of the profits, but successive Quebec governments have refused to re-open the deal.
In January, however, both sides agreed to begin discussing the issue.
At the New England governors and Eastern Canadian premiers conference in Newport, R.I. on Wednesday, Newfoundland Premier Brian Tobin hinted that the talks were advancing.

Newfoundland is also mulling the development of a massive hydro-electric project on the Lower Churchill River, a plan that has been on the backburner for many years because the remote Atlantic province would need technological and financial partners to build it.

Newfoundland's natural partner for the 17 billion kilowatt hour Lower Churchill Falls project would be Hydro-Quebec. But the recent deregulation of the U.S. hydro-electric energy market and the opening of Hydro-Quebec's power grid to allow the trans-shipment of power from other producers allowed Newfoundland to seek other partners.
In Newport, Tobin indicated that Newfoundland was prepared to do that.
Quebec's Chevrette said Hydro-Quebec had the expertise to help develop the Lower Churchill, and he suggested that talks on that project could be linked to the existing power contract.

"Could it be mutually advantageous to negotiate things relating to existing contracts in accordance with future implications? I leave to the experts the task of making an analysis and recommendations," he said.
A working group on the talks is expected to report to the Newfoundland and Quebec premiers by September.
